text:
THE INTEGRAL CALCULUS

 Basic Integration

The integral calculus is concerned with the inverse problem: if the rate of change of a function is known, what is the function itself? In other words, a function y has to be found when the derivative dy/dx is given. 

Integration is just the direct opposite of differentiation. It "works back" the derivative of a function to the root function itself. We will discuss basic integration and the tools you would need to evaluate different kinds of integrals.

Below is a list of different functions with their derivatives and integrals compared. Notice the similarities and differences among them.

                         Derivative

                              Integral

d/dx (xn)=nxn-1

int(xn)dx=xn+1/n+1 + C except n=-1 PS: When n=-1, xn=x-1=1/x

d/dx(ax+b)n= a n(ax+b)n-1

int(ax+b)n= 1/a (ax+b)n+1/n+1 + C

d/dx(sin x)=cos x

int(cos x)=sin x

d/dx(cos x)= - sin x

int(sin x)= - cos x

d/dx(tan x)=sec2x

int(sec2x)=tan x + C

d/dx(cot x)= - cosec2x

int(cosec2x)= - cot x + C

d/dx sin(ax+b)= a cos(ax+b)

int cos(ax+b)= 1/a sin(ax+b) + C

d/dx cos(ax+b)= - a sin(ax+b)

int sin(ax+b)= -1/a cos(ax+b) + C

d/dx tan(ax+b)= a sec2(ax+b)

int sec2(ax+b)= 1/a tan(ax+b) + C

d/dx cot(ax+b)= - a cosec2(ax+b)

int cosec2(ax+b)= - 1/a cot(ax+b) + C

d/dx In(x) = 1/x

int (1/x) = In(x) + C

           

                                                                        fig 1

 

Q1:  Evaluate the integral of 1+x2

Solution

1+x2=x0+x2.  Applying the the formula for the basic Integral, int(xn)dx=xn+1/n+1 + C to each term,

int(1+x2)= x0+1/(0+1) + x2+1 /(2+1) 

:. int(1+x2) = x + x3/3 + C

 

Q2: What is the integral of (x2+1/x2) ?

Solution

Notice (x2+1/x2) = x2/x2 + 1/x2 = 1 + x-2 = x0+x-2

:. int (x2+1/x2) = x0+1/0+1 + x-2+1/-2+1

= x-x-1 = x -1/x

 

Q3: Given that f'(x)=3x2-6x+1 and f(3)=5, find the original function f(x).

Solution

f'(x) is the derivative of the function. Given f'(x), we integrate this term to determine f(x). 

Since we know the value of this function, f(x) for x=3, we can also determine the value of the constant C usually included after integrating a function. 

So, effectively, we will be able to write the function completely for x.

int f'(x) = 3x3/3 - 6x2/2 + x= x3 -3x2+x+C

ie f(x)=x3 -3x2+x+C 

:. f(3)=33-3(3)2+3+C=5 => C=5-3=2

:. f(x)=x3-3x2+x+2

 

Q4: Evaluate int [3x2-2x-12]3-2 dx

Solution

This is an example of the definite integral, "definite" because we are going to evaluate this integral numerically for the above limits. 

The upper limit, (superscript) is 3 while the lower limit, or subscript is -2. The two numbers represent the limit of the definite integral.

 

This is similar to the how we evaluate the derivative of a function at a given point, say x= -3, written dy/dx|x=-3.

It's also worth noting that the value of the definite integral represents the area under the graph of the function and the x-axis for the chosen limits. 

This means that the above question could be rephrased thus: " What is the area b/w the curve of 3x2-2x-12 and the x-axis for the interval [-2,3]?".

When we proceed,

int (3x2-2x-12) = 3x3/3 - 2x2/2 -12x = x3-x2-12x 

To evaluate the indefinite integral for the limits, we substitute x for -2 and 3 and then subtract the lower limit from the upper limit.

UL: 33-32-12(3) = -18

LW: (-2)3-(-2)2-12(-2) = -8-4+24 = 12

:. [3x2-2x-12]3-2 dx, the area b/w the curve of 3x2-2x-12 and the x-axis for the interval [-2,3] = -18-12 = -30 sq units

 

Q5: Evaluate the definite integral [sec22x]π/80 dx

Solution

We can quickly write down the integral from the table given in fig 1 above. 

:. int (sec22x)= ½ tan(2x)

UL: ½tan(2×π/8) = ½tan(π/4) = ½  given tan(π/4)=tan 45°= 1

LW: ½ tan(2×0) = 0

:. [sec22x]π/80 dx = ½ - 0 = ½ 

 

Q6: What is the integral with respect to x of the following functions (i) 2sin(3-2x) (ii) cos (1+x) 

Solution

(i) int 2sin(3-2x) = int 2sin(-2x+3)

In this form, a = - 2. From fig 1 above, 

int sin(ax+b)= - 1/a cos (ax+b) + C

=> - ½ [- 2 cos (-2x+3) ] = cos(3-2x) + C

 

(ii) a=1 and applying int cos(ax+b)= 1/a sin(ax+b) 

:. int cos (1+x) = sin(x+1) + C

 

Pume Example

If  = 6x - 3 and y(-1) = 8, find y(x).

A. 3x2 - 3x – 8, B. 3x2 - 3x + 8, C. 3x2 – 3x – 2, D. 3x2 - 3x + 2 

D (2007/2008, no 11).

Given that,  = 6x – 3

We cross multiply

dx(6x – 3) = dy

dy = dx(6x – 3)

We integrate 

= 

y =  3x + C

y = 3x2 – 3x  + C

Given that y(-1) = 8

y(x) = 3x2 – 3x  + C = 8

y(-1) = 3(-1)2 – 3(-1)  + C = 8

= 3 + 3 + C = 8

C = 2

 y = 3x2 – 3x + 2

 

Example

Find the area of region enclosed by the curve y = 2 — x2 and the line y = -x.

A. 3/2, B. 9, C. 3, D. -9/2

 

D (2008/2009, no 13).

The ordinates can be optained by equating the curve and the line

y = 2 — x2, y = -x

2 — x2 = -x

Collect like terms

x2 – x – 2 = 0 ……. (eq1)

(x – 2)(x + 1) = 0

x – 2 = 0

x = 2

x + 1 = 0

x = -1 

the area can be determined by integrating equation 1

Example

Evaluate 

A. 0, B. 5, C. ∞, D. 1

 

B (2007/2008, no 10).

 

 

Applying L’Hopital’s rule, 

g(x) = x2 + x – 6 

h(x) = x – 2.

x = +2

g'(x) = 2x + 1

h’(x) = 1

 =  

Substituting for x

=  = 5
